description: Indicates the connectivity of this user with this environment. Values map to discrete measure values (Poor, Weak, Strong, None).
interpretation: This measure reports categorical values (Poor connection, Weak connection, Strong connection, None) which are represented numerically in graphs. A major alert is raised for 'Poor connection'; a minor alert for 'Weak connection'.
troubleshootingSteps: Verify the user has an active session on the RDS host and check session host and broker logs for authentication/session errors.
Confirm network connectivity (ping/traceroute) between client and server; check for high latency or packet loss.
Ensure the user account is enabled, not locked out, and that RDS licensing (CALs) is available.
Test from a different client or network to determine if the problem is client-specific.
Collect timelines and session creation logs to correlate with reported poor-quality events.

description: Indicates the average time taken for encoding the frames of this user.
interpretation: Compare this value across users to find which user's frames took longer to encode; high values may indicate CPU/GPU contention on the host.
troubleshootingSteps: Check RDS host CPU and GPU utilization during the affected period for contention.
Verify graphics codec and GPU driver versions on the host and update if needed.
Ensure hardware acceleration is enabled when supported and not oversubscribed by other sessions.
Temporarily reduce client resolution or color depth to validate if encoding time improves.
Review host-side background tasks that may spike CPU or GPU usage and reschedule them.

description: Indicates the quality of the output frame expressed as a percentage of the quality of the source frame for this user.
interpretation: Higher percentages indicate better fidelity. Compare across users to identify the user with the poorest visual quality.
troubleshootingSteps: Compare frame quality across affected and unaffected users to isolate client vs server issues.
Check network bandwidth, packet loss and jitter; poor network conditions reduce frame quality.
Verify codec and compression settings on the RDS host and consider reducing compression where bandwidth allows.
Update Remote Desktop client and client display drivers; test from a different client to isolate the issue.
Capture screenshots or short session recordings for visual analysis.

measurement: Frames skipped due to insufficient client resources
description: Indicates the rate at which frames were skipped for this user due to insufficient client resources.
interpretation: A low value is desired; high values indicate the client device may lack CPU/GPU/memory resources.
troubleshootingSteps: Confirm the client device meets minimum Remote Desktop requirements and is not CPU or memory constrained.
Check client-side CPU, GPU and memory usage and close unnecessary applications.
Update the Remote Desktop client and client display drivers; verify thin client firmware if applicable.
Reduce client resolution or color depth to lower rendering workload and validate improvement.
Test the session from a known-good client to determine if the issue is client-specific.

measurement: Frames skipped due to insufficient network resources
description: Indicates the rate at which frames were skipped for this user due to insufficient network resources.
interpretation: A low value is desired; high values point to undersized or lossy networks between client and server.
troubleshootingSteps: Measure client-to-server bandwidth and latency (iperf, speedtest, ping) during the issue window.
Check for packet loss, congestion or interface errors on the LAN/WAN path; use traceroute or mtr where available.
If the client is on Wi‑Fi, test on a wired connection to rule out wireless issues.
Inspect QoS policies that may throttle RDP/UDP traffic and adjust as necessary.
Capture network traces (pcap) on client and server for detailed analysis.

measurement: Frames skipped due to insufficient server resources
description: Indicates the rate at which frames were skipped for this user due to insufficient server resources.
interpretation: A low value is desired; high values suggest host-side resource contention or overload.
troubleshootingSteps: Monitor host CPU, memory and GPU utilization during affected sessions to identify contention.
Check concurrent session counts and host capacity; consider scaling out or load balancing.
Verify hypervisor GPU passthrough/configuration and driver health on the host.
Migrate the affected user to a different host to determine if the issue follows a host.
Schedule heavy background tasks outside peak hours and tune per-session resource limits.

description: Indicates the ratio of the number of bytes encoded to the number of bytes input for this user.
interpretation: Higher compression ratios typically reduce picture quality; lower values are preferred (closer to 0).
troubleshootingSteps: Review encoder/compression settings on the RDS host and reduce compression if bandwidth permits.
Check for network constraints that force higher compression; improving bandwidth may allow better quality.
Verify client and server codec compatibility and update drivers/firmware as needed.
Test the session from a different client or network to confirm if compression is network-driven or host-driven.

description: Indicates the number of source frames provided per second as input to the RemoteFX graphics for this user.
interpretation: Higher input frame rates indicate more change at the source (video, animations); compare across users to find heavy graphical workloads.
troubleshootingSteps: Identify applications generating frequent screen updates (video players, dashboards) and reduce unnecessary activity.
If undesirable, ask the user to close or reduce visual workloads to lower input frames.
Profile source applications for refresh loops or misbehaving components and fix where possible.
Use a test session to reproduce and capture recordings to correlate activity with input frame spikes.

description: Indicates the number of source frames sent per second to this user as output of RemoteFX graphics.
interpretation: Output frames show how many frames are delivered to the client. Low output relative to input may indicate throttling, compression, or drops.
troubleshootingSteps: Compare input versus output frames to determine whether frames are being dropped or aggregated.
Check network transmission metrics (bandwidth, packet loss, latency) that may force frame reduction.
Inspect server encoding performance and latency that could limit output frame rate.
Verify client capabilities (refresh rate, display settings) that might limit rendered output frames.

description: Indicates number of frames per second composed at the source for this user.
interpretation: Reflects how often the server-side desktop changes; high values indicate dynamic content, low values indicate stability.
troubleshootingSteps: Identify windows or applications that cause frequent redraws and reduce refresh intervals if possible.
Check for background tasks or scripts that frequently update the UI and adjust them.
Profile composition operations and enable or verify GPU acceleration where helpful.
Capture screen recordings to correlate source activity with frame composition rates.

description: Indicates the amount of data currently carried over TCP for this user.
interpretation: A steady rise could indicate that TCP traffic to/from the user is consuming bandwidth excessively; compare across users to find high usage.
troubleshootingSteps: Monitor per-user TCP throughput over time to determine whether high usage is sustained or bursty.
Identify applications or transfers generating high TCP traffic and validate expected behavior.
Apply QoS or traffic-shaping policies to limit per-user bandwidth if appropriate.
Run controlled throughput tests (iperf) to validate end-to-end capacity and isolate bottlenecks.

description: Indicates the amount of data currently carried over UDP for this user.
interpretation: A consistent rise could indicate UDP traffic is consuming bandwidth; compare across users to find intensive flows.
troubleshootingSteps: Monitor UDP throughput and correlate with application behavior (audio/video, real-time streams).
Check for UDP policers, ACLs or filtering on network devices that may limit traffic.
Test from a different network or wired connection to rule out local path constraints.
Capture UDP flows for timing analysis and work with the network team to ensure low-latency paths.

description: Indicates the percentage of forward error corrections performed for this user.
interpretation: FEC is used to recover lost UDP packets; a higher value indicates more recovered packets and may improve responsiveness.
troubleshootingSteps: If FEC rate is high, validate whether recovery prevented user impact and examine underlying loss sources.
If loss is high but FEC is low, confirm FEC is enabled and configured correctly on both ends.
Capture UDP flows to validate FEC packets and recovery behavior for sample sessions.
Work with network team to reduce underlying packet loss rather than relying only on FEC.

description: Indicates the percentage of packets lost when being transmitted to this user.
interpretation: High values indicate significant packet loss that will degrade experience; compare across users to find worst-affected connections.
troubleshootingSteps: Run continuous pings and packet captures to determine where loss is occurring (client, LAN, WAN, server).
Check physical links and switch/router interfaces for errors, CRC drops or configuration problems.
If on Wi‑Fi, test on a wired connection to rule out wireless-related loss.
Coordinate with ISP or network provider to remediate link-level issues if loss occurs outside the local network.

description: Indicates the percentage of packets that have been retransmitted to this user.
interpretation: Elevated retransmission rates (over ~5%) can indicate degraded LAN performance; extremely high values (>25%) greatly impact transfer times and UX.
troubleshootingSteps: Correlate retransmission spikes with packet loss and latency metrics to identify root cause.
Inspect MTU settings and fragmentation that may cause retransmissions.
Validate NIC drivers and firmware on client and server and update if necessary.
Perform TCP diagnostics (netstat, counters) and capture traces to observe duplicate ACKs and retransmission triggers.

description: Indicates the rate at which data is received over TCP for this user.
interpretation: Higher rates typically indicate healthy TCP throughput for inbound traffic.
troubleshootingSteps: Confirm high received rates align with expected activity (downloads, streaming).
If rates are unexpectedly low, run iperf to test end-to-end TCP throughput and identify bottlenecks.
Inspect for packet loss or retransmissions that might reduce effective throughput.
Tune TCP window sizes or congestion control if applicable for the environment.

description: Indicates the rate at which data is sent over TCP for this user.
interpretation: Higher rates indicate higher outbound TCP throughput from the client to server.
troubleshootingSteps: Validate server-side applications generating outbound TCP traffic and check logs for expected transfers.
Check server NIC settings (offload, checksumming) and egress queues for abnormalities.
Run controlled throughput tests to validate send capacity and eliminate network bottlenecks.
Coordinate with network team to ensure upstream capacity and QoS policies meet requirements.

description: Indicates the time between initiating a network request and receiving a response over TCP for this user.
interpretation: High values may indicate a bottleneck in TCP connectivity between the user terminal and the server. This measure may not be reported if both TCP Received Rate and TCP Sent Rate are 0.
troubleshootingSteps: Measure baseline TCP RTT using ping or tcping and compare to historical baselines.
Check for device congestion, queuing or ISP issues along the path between client and server.
If using VPN or WAN links, validate tunnel health and any acceleration devices that might add latency.
Collect traceroute and packet captures for detailed path analysis.

description: Indicates the average time between initiating a network request and receiving a response over TCP for this user.
interpretation: High values indicate current TCP connectivity problems; this measure may not be reported if there is no active TCP traffic (sent and received rates are 0).
troubleshootingSteps: Perform real-time latency tests (ping, tcping) from the client to the server to confirm current RTT.
Check for transient congestion, route changes or maintenance affecting latency during the observed window.
Inspect client local network (Wi‑Fi interference, duplex mismatches) for contributors to latency.
Collect packet traces during the event to identify retransmissions or delayed ACKs that inflate RTT.

description: Indicates the rate at which data is received over UDP for this user.
interpretation: Higher values indicate higher UDP throughput for inbound traffic.
troubleshootingSteps: Confirm UDP traffic corresponds to expected RemoteFX or real-time streams and not unexpected noise.
If received rate is low, check for UDP filtering, ACLs or policing that may limit traffic.
Measure UDP capacity with iperf (UDP mode) to validate path performance.
Capture UDP flows and work with network team to ensure low-latency handling for media.

description: Indicates the rate at which data is sent over UDP for this user.
interpretation: Higher values indicate higher outbound UDP throughput from the client to server.
troubleshootingSteps: Verify the server/client are generating expected UDP streams and inspect for bursty patterns.
Check network devices for UDP policers, ACLs or rate limits that affect sending rates.
Capture UDP traffic to analyze timing, payloads and any FEC behavior.
Coordinate with network and server teams to prioritize real-time traffic where appropriate.

description: Indicates the time between initiating a network request and receiving a response over UDP for this user.
interpretation: High values may indicate a bottleneck in UDP connectivity; this measure may not be reported if both UDP Received Rate and UDP Sent Rate are 0.
troubleshootingSteps: Measure UDP RTT using iperf (UDP mode) or specialized UDP latency tools and compare to baseline.
Check for packet loss and jitter on the path that can inflate UDP RTT.
Inspect intermediate devices for UDP rate-limiting, policing or NAT behavior adding delay.
Capture UDP flows for timing analysis and coordinate with the network team.

description: Indicates the average time between initiating a network request and receiving a response over UDP for this user.
interpretation: High values indicate current UDP connectivity problems; this measure may not be reported if there is no active UDP traffic.
troubleshootingSteps: Measure UDP RTT with UDP-capable tools and compare to baseline to detect anomalies.
Check for network jitter, packet loss, or intermediate buffering that affects UDP timing.
Test from a wired connection if the client is on Wi‑Fi to rule out wireless-induced issues.
If persistent, collect packet captures and work with network team or ISP to remediate.
